MLRA_2015_2_606.JUDGMENT_NAME: UR LEISURE RESORTS SDN BHD v. MALAYAN BANKING BERHAD
MLRA_2015_2_606.JUDGE_NAME: Mohd Hishamudin Yunus, Aziah Ali, Lim Yee Lan JJCA

p.i: Land Law: Sale of land - Order for - Land held under Land Office title - Application to Land Administrator for sale of land - Land Administrator referring application to High Court due to chargor's disagreement with reserve price - No two previous unsuccessful sales - High Court making order for sale under s 265(3A) National Land Code - Whether High Court empowered to make such order for sale under s 265(3A) - Whether Land Administrator erred in making such reference to High Court

Statutory Interpretation: Construction of statutes - Aids to construction - Explanatory statement to bill - Clause in explanatory statement not containing full and clear explanation as to purpose of amendments to provision in statute - Whether such clause in explanatory statement of little utility

HEADNOTE.p: The appellant was the registered proprietor of a piece of land ("the land"). He charged the land to the respondent as security for a loan taken by a third party. The land was held under a Land Office title. The third party defaulted and the respondent applied to the Land Administrator for the sale of the land pursuant to s 260 of the National Land Code ("NLC"). The Land Administrator held an inquiry but did not make any order for sale. Instead, purporting to act under s 265(3A) of the NLC, the Land Administrator referred the application to the High Court. The Land Administrator did so because the appellant had disagreed with the reserve price proposed by the respondent. The High Court, purporting to act under s 265(3A) of the NLC, made an order for sale. The appellant appealed to the Court of Appeal. In the Court of Appeal, the appellant submitted that since there were no two unsuccessful auctions before the Land Administrator carried out pursuant to subsections (1), (2) and (3) of s 265 of the NLC, the Land Administrator had no power under s 265(3A) of the NLC to refer the application to the High Court. Further, since the High Court had no power to make the order for sale, the purported order for sale by the High Court was a nullity.
Held, allowing the appeal with costs:

(1) This court could not agree with the interpretation that subsection (3A) of s 265 of the NLC should be read independently of subsections (2) and (3) of s 265, and that the High Court has the power to make an order for sale under subsection (3A) provided there was a reference to the High Court by the Land Administrator, even where there had been no two previous unsuccessful sales. (para 14)

(2) With the introduction of subsection (3A), the position does not change; there still must have been two prior unsuccessful sales by the Land Administrator before he can lawfully refer the matter to the High Court. The amendment only makes clear via a proviso to subsection (3A) that the High Court cannot, in exercising its power under subsection (3A), make an order to direct the Land Administrator to carry out a sale. Under the pre-amended provision of subsection (3), it is not made clear whether the High Court, in dealing with the reference, had the power to make an order for sale directing the Land Administrator to carry out the sale. (para 14)

(3) Clause 30 of the Explanatory Statement to the National Land Code (Amendment) Bill 2000, as referred to by counsel for the respondent, was of no assistance to the construction of either the amended subsection (3) or the new subsection (3A). It did not contain a full and clear explanation as to the purpose of the amendments to s 265. The clause was mere lip service to explain the purposes of the amendments and was of little utility. Significantly, cl 30 had omitted to even mention - let alone to explain - the purpose of, among others, the proviso to subsection (3A). (para 15)

p.p: Explanatory Statement to the National Land Code (Amendment) Bill 2000, cl 30

p.i: For the appellant: Hardeep Singh Jessy; M/s Hardeep Gurvin & Co
For the respondent: Ramsun Ho Chii Huey; M/s See Ramsun & Tan

JUDGMENT.p: [1] This appeal concerns a question of law: Whether a Land Administrator has the power pursuant to subsection (3A) of s 265 of the National Land Code ('the NLC') to refer an application for sale, made to the Land Administrator pursuant to s 260 of the NLC, to the High Court, without previously having carried out a sale of the subject land at the Land Office twice pursuant to subsections (1), (2) and (3) of s 265 of the National Land Code.

[3] The appellant was the registered proprietor of the subject land. The subject land was charged to the respondent bank on 17 February 1996 as security for a loan taken by a third party. The third party defaulted on the loan. As the subject land was held under a Land Office title, the respondent on 28 March 2006 proceeded to apply to the Land Administrator for the sale of the land pursuant to s 260 of the NLC.

[4] It is not disputed that an inquiry was held before the Land Administrator on various dates (the last date being 20 December 2011), but the Land Administrator did not make any order for sale in respect of the subject land pursuant to s 263 of the NLC. Instead, purporting to act under s 265(3A) of the NLC, the Land Administrator 'referred' the application to the High Court.

[5] In the case before us the Land Administrator purported to refer the application to the High Court via his letter dated 2 January 2012 because (according to para 3 of the letter) the appellant/chargor had disagreed with the reserved price as proposed by the respondent/chargee, and had applied that the matter be referred to the High Court.
[6] The High Court purporting to act under s 265(3A) made an order for sale.

[7] Before us the appellant submitted that, since there were no two unsuccessful auctions before the Land Administrator carried out pursuant to subsections (1), (2) and (3) of s 265 of the NLC, the Land Administrator had no power under subsection (3A) of s 265 to refer the application to the High Court. Since the purported reference to the High Court was an invalid reference, a nullity, it follows then that the High Court had no power to make the order for sale; and that the purported order for sale by the High Court was a nullity.

[8] The respondent, on the other hand, takes the position that subsection (3A) of s 265 was inserted via an amendment to s 265 and the purpose of this amendment is to confer power to the Land Administrator to refer any application for sale to the High Court regardless of whether or not there had been prior unsuccessful sale (or sales) before the Land Administrator. In support of its argument, the learned counsel for the respondent refers to para 30 of the Explanatory Statement to the National Land Code (Amendment) Bill 2000 which states:

[9] The learned High Court Judge takes the view that subsection (3A) of s 265 must be read independently of subsections (2) and (3) of the same; and that this must be the intention of Parliament when it amended s 265 via the National Land Code (Amendment) Act 2001 (Act A1104) that came into force on 1 December 2001 by deleting subsection (3)(c) of that section and introduced subsection (3A).
[10] The learned High Court Judge said in his judgment:
[11] Dissatisfied with the decision of the High Court, the appellant/defendant appealed to the Court of Appeal.

p.b: Subsection (3) Of Section 265 Of The NLC Prior To The Amendment

JUDGMENT.p: [12] Prior to the amendment of subsection (3) of s 265, the subsection reads:

[13] On 26 May 2014 we allowed the appellant's/defendant's appeal with costs. We set aside the Order of the High Court as well as the decision of the Land Administrator to refer the matter to the High Court.We order that the matter be sent back to the Land Administrator to carry out a proper inquiry in accordance with the provisions of s 261 of the NLC and to make the appropriate decision under s 263 of the same.

[14] With respect, we are unable to agree with the interpretation as adopted by the learned High Court Judge that subsection (3A) of s 265 should be read independently of subsections (2) and (3) of the same; and that the High Court has the power to make an order for sale under subsection (3A), provided there was a reference to the High Court by the Land Administrator, even where there had been no two previous unsuccessful sales (in the sense of there being no bidders). If subsection (3A) were to be read independently of subsections (2) and (3), as ruled by the learned High Court Judge, then how does one explain the meaning of the words:

in the present subsection (3)? These words will only make sense if we were to read them together with subsection (3A). We are of the view that it is clear that, with the introduction of subsection (3A), the position does not change: there still must have been two prior unsuccessful sales by the Land Administrator before he can lawfully refer the matter to the High Court. What the amendment now makes clear - and this is via a proviso to subsection (3A) - is that the High Court cannot, in exercising its power under subsection (3A), that is to say, in dealing with the reference, make an order to direct the Land Administrator to carry out a sale. Under the pre-amended provision of subsection (3), it is not made clear as to whether or not the High Court, in dealing with the reference, had the power to make an order directing the Land Administrator to carry out the sale.

[15] We find that cl 30 of the Explanatory Statement to the Bill, as referred to by the learned counsel for the respondent, is of no assistance to the construction of either the amended subsection (3) or the new subsection (3A). It does not contain a full and clear explanation as to the purpose of the amendments to s 265, and this is unfortunate. With respect to the Parliamentary Draftsman, we view the clause as a mere lip service effort to explain the purposes of the amendments; of little utility; and, significantly, cl 30 had omitted to even mention (let alone to explain the purpose of), among others, the proviso to subsection (3A).

p.i: [Appeal allowed with costs; Order of High Court set aside; matter send back to the Land Administrator to hold an inquiry in accordance with the NLC]
